commit_message:
Publish draft releasenotes

Upload the generated draft releasenotes so that they can be easily
reviewed - similar to documents with just clicking on the gate.

Rename the job to gate-{name}-releasenotes, the tox is not needed
anymore in the name.

Change-Id: Ib542084a275a5bfe82c48517d48372fec6411e16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/92/245592/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - 'gate-{name}-releasenotes' - name: ^gate-.*-releasenotes$ success-pattern: http://docs-draft.openstack.org/{build.parameters[LOG_PATH]}/releasenotes/build/html/

commit_message:
[Docs restructuring] Storage requirements

Added a section about storage requirements

Change-Id: I435510b2ab76b95082fd8b809425badf68a3eac4
Partial-Bug: #1504699
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/75/238275/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _sysreq_storge_reqs: Storage requirements ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ When planning storage, understand the difference between the two types of storage that OpenStack uses: persistent and ephemeral. The nova-compute service manages ephemeral storage that is used as temporary storage for operating system of virtual machine instances. When you delete an instance, nova-compute deletes the ephemeral storage as well. If you do not select any additional storage options, the virtual machine volumes will be stored on the local disks of the compute nodes, in the virtual storage partition. However, if you enable Ceph RBD backend for ephemeral volumes, nova-compute stores ephemeral volumes in Ceph. Persistent storage is the storage that exists outside an instance, in contrast to ephemeral storage. Fuel deploys storage for two types of persistent data: * Glance, for image data, which can use either Swift or Ceph RBD as the storage backend. * Cinder, for block data, which can use either LVM or Ceph RBD as the storage backend. .. seealso:: - `Storage Decisions <http://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ops/content/storage_decision.html>`_

commit_message:
Remove verbose code for hive metastore schema creation in MapR plugin

Use a property datanucleus.autoCreateSchema which creates schema on
startup if one does not exist.

Change-Id: I08421aae16cbddd810557734b680d986018b9139
Implements: blueprint hive-metastore-setup
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/00/240700/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <name>datanucleus.autoCreateSchema</name> <value>true</value> <description> creates necessary schema on a startup if one doesn't exist. </description> </property> <property>

commit_message:
Run py34 first in default tox run

this avoids py34 failure in default tox run when testrepository is
not yet initialized (e.g. fresh repo clone).

Change-Id: I7aa1817cfac3a60e6faabd1b21be736857b4c103
Closes-Bug: #1489059

added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pep8

commit_message:
Adding autogenerated saharaclient API docs

Saharaclient API docs now can be autogenerated, that
prevents them from manual update. Also docstrings
were added to describe some unclear parameters.

Change-Id: Ibf9fdf332c91cdfb18d6f8ec5429a39dc2862494

commit_message:
Add stable/liberty tripleo job

Recently tripleo created stable/liberty branches for several repos, ref
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/221811/, this adds an initial job
which will test using these new branches.

Add 'Fixing I18n bugs' to contributing.rst

Change-Id: If505cb482a81e2fcd0d5a977cc0a3ca0363fac38

added_lines: Internationalization (I18n) is essential to make OpenStack ubiquitous. The mission of OpenStack I18n team is to make OpenStack ubiquitously accessible to people of all language backgrounds, by enhancing OpenStack software internationalization, providing translation, maintaining a translation platform and managing translation process for better quality of outcomes.

commit_message:
tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration: use d-g for tempest

Use devstack-gate scripts to configure tempest.
Then hook in nova will only run initial tempest test
and make configuration changes then

Change-Id: Ic6ff3446f4c549f99ccc5248ff449b2201c24eee

Adding mistral specs repo

After discussion with Mistral core team, we decided to adopt the
specification approval process, like other official projects.

Change-Id: I7da1ffaee454383704beb94b0c2bc9786dd1846f

commit_message:
Enabled lightweight jobs for stable branches of fuel-repos

To unblock merge to stable branches this commit:
* enable pep8 jobs for python repos
* enable puppet-lint job for puppet repo

Change-Id: I5fb79e7d6d643b2b09a50fa23c28833f7992db03

deleted_lines: class TestMidonetInterfaceDriver(TestBase): def setUp(self): self.conf = config.setup_conf() self.conf.register_opts(interface.OPTS) self.driver = interface.MidonetInterfaceDriver(self.conf) self.network_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self.port_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self.device_name = "tap0" self.mac_address = "aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff" self.bridge = "br-test" self.namespace = "ns-test" super(TestMidonetInterfaceDriver, self).setUp() def test_plug(self): cmd = ['mm-ctl', '--bind-port', self.port_id, 'tap0'] self.device_exists.return_value = False root_dev = mock.Mock() ns_dev = mock.Mock() self.ip().add_veth = mock.Mock(return_value=(root_dev, ns_dev)) with mock.patch.object(utils, 'execute') as execute: self.driver.plug( self.network_id, self.port_id, self.device_name, self.mac_address, self.bridge, self.namespace) execute.assert_called_once_with(cmd, run_as_root=True) expected = [mock.call(), mock.call(), mock.call().add_veth(self.device_name, self.device_name, namespace2=self.namespace), mock.call().ensure_namespace(self.namespace), mock.call().ensure_namespace().add_device_to_namespace( mock.ANY)] ns_dev.assert_has_calls( [mock.call.link.set_address(self.mac_address)]) root_dev.assert_has_calls([mock.call.link.set_up()]) ns_dev.assert_has_calls([mock.call.link.set_up()]) self.ip.assert_has_calls(expected, True) def test_unplug(self): self.driver.unplug(self.device_name, self.bridge, self.namespace) self.ip_dev.assert_has_calls([ mock.call(self.device_name, namespace=self.namespace), mock.call().link.delete()]) self.ip.assert_has_calls([mock.call().garbage_collect_namespace()])

added_lines: acl get Retrieve ACLs for a secret or container by providing its href. acl delete Delete ACLs for a secret or container as identified by its href. acl submit Submit ACL on a secret or container as identified by its href. acl user add Add ACL users to a secret or container as identified by its href. acl user remove Remove ACL users from a secret or container as identified by its href. ca get Retrieve a CA by providing its URI. ca list List cas. complete print bash completion command secret container create Store a container in Barbican. secret container delete Delete a container by providing its href. secret container get Retrieve a container by providing its URI. secret container list List containers. help print detailed help for another command secret order create Create a new order. secret order delete Delete an order by providing its href. secret order get Retrieve an order by providing its URI. secret order list List orders. secret delete Delete an secret by providing its href. secret get Retrieve a secret by providing its URI. secret list List secrets. secret store Store a secret in Barbican secret update Update a secret with no payload in Barbican.

commit_message:
Rename get_job_status to get_job_info in oozie.py

get_job_status actually get job's info in oozie.py, rename it to
get_job_info to avoid the confusion.

Change-Id: I0628bcd0760b45e8345027f4dbd1e6c5d7c6e9fd
Closes-bug: 1515706

commit_message:
ES6size app.js

app.js now mostly uses ES6 syntax. This commit also moves
initialization of the app to a separate method and removes
a hack for ajax callbacks - we don't need it anymore.

Change-Id: Iba48469d195601e6bf450f1d33ba1db4a9a666bc

commit_message:
Pick up Lock Breaker from TODO items

Work items:
- Add a function to check engine status,
  and a timeout option in config.
- Add steal operation for lock_acquire.

Reference:
[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/senlin/+spec/lock-breaker
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/senlin/+bug/1514742

Change-Id: I1dbb3068496465a9c84810a819a9bdac43f9272b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/71/244471/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: ENGINE ------ - Lock breaker in multi-engine environment to pevent objects being locked by dead engine.

commit_message:
Sql database in installation guide with wrong python package name

The package python2-PyMySQL doesn't exist:

controller:root:/etc/glance> yum search python2-PyMySQL
Loaded plugins: fastestmirror
Loading mirror speeds from cached hostfile
 * base: centos1.hti.pl
 * epel: ftp.pbone.net
 * extras: centos1.hti.pl
 * updates: centos1.hti.pl
Warning: No matches found for: python2-PyMySQL
No matches found
2015-11-08 22:09:47 yum search python2-PyMySQL

However the package specified in the Kilo doc exists:

controller:root:/etc/glance> yum search MySQL-python
Loaded plugins: fastestmirror
Loading mirror speeds from cached hostfile
 * base: centos1.hti.pl
 * epel: ftp.pbone.net
 * extras: centos1.hti.pl
 * updates: centos1.hti.pl
===========================================
=========================
N/S matched: MySQL-python ================
===========================================
=========
MySQL-python.x86_64 : An interface to MySQL

Closes-Bug: #1514248

commit_message:
DRAFT Sync UI and Templated Networking

Ironic integration requires adding an optional network role and network.

Let's discuss how can this be achieved in the current state of the art
in Fuel and its Templated Networking feature.

Specifies blueprint sync-ui-and-templated-networking

Change-Id: Id84a6215652d9f83838861bb7bfb38a1dcdfc482
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/19/225619/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================== Sync templated netwroking representation and UI =============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/sync-ui-and-templated-networking -------------------- Problem description -------------------- Currently the full networking setup in Fuel is possible in two mutually exclusive ways - with Fuel UI or with Templated Networking. When Templated Networking is in action, the UI page for configuring the network interfaces on nodes is completely disabled. Ironic integration into MOS requires creating a new network role and a new network for baremetal instances. As Ironic is optional component, ideally these should be created only in case Ironic was chosen for deployment from UI, and removed when it is not chosen. Currently for integrated components adding an optional network/role is supported in "templated networking" configuration mode only, which has no sync with UI, does not accept changes from UI, and blocks further usage of UI. Also usage of Templated Networking feature requires careful building of the whole networking representation as a template, limiting it to power-users only. ---------------- Proposed changes ---------------- Have a two-way sync between the UI for networking settings and Templated Networking. Web UI ====== TBD Nailgun ======= TBD Data model ---------- TBD REST API -------- TBD Orchestration ============= TBD RPC Protocol ------------ None? Fuel Client =========== None Plugins ======= TBD Fuel Library ============ TBD ------------ Alternatives ------------ Alternative 1 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Pre-create the internal representation of baremetal network(-role) for all environments, but hide it from UI when Ironic is not chosen. This is the approach our currently proposed changes to Nailgun [1] are following. Alternative 2 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Allow creating network roles via Fuel API. Ironic team might consider a UX trade-off in this case, requiring user to first execute some commands in CLI (creating a network role and network itself) *before* activating Ironic from UI. -------------- Upgrade impact -------------- TBD --------------- Security impact --------------- TBD -------------------- Notifications impact -------------------- TBD --------------- End user impact --------------- TBD ------------------ Performance impact ------------------ TBD ----------------- Deployment impact ----------------- TBD ---------------- Developer impact ---------------- TBD -------------------------------- Infrastructure/operations impact -------------------------------- TBD -------------------- Documentation impact -------------------- TBD -------------------- Expected OSCI impact -------------------- TBD -------------- Implementation -------------- Assignee(s) =========== Primary assignee: ashestakov TBD Other contributors: pshchelo TBD Mandatory design review: alekseyk-ru xenolog vkramskikh ikalnistky Work Items ========== TBD Dependencies ============ TBD ------------ Testing, QA ------------ TBD Acceptance criteria =================== TBD ---------- References ---------- [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/223626

added_lines: This script builds Ubuntu, Fedora, CentOS cloud images for use in Sahara. By default the all plugin are targeted, all images will be built. The '-p' option can be used to select plugin (vanilla, spark, hdp or cloudera, plain). The '-i' option can be used to select image type (ubuntu, fedora or centos). The '-v' option can be used to select hadoop version (1, 2 etc).1. Use your environment (export / setenv) to alter the scripts behavior. Environment variables the script accepts are 'DIB_HADOOP_VERSION_1' and 'DIB_HADOOP_VERSION_2', 'JAVA_DOWNLOAD_URL', 'JAVA_TARGET_LOCATION', 'OOZIE_DOWNLOAD_URL', 'HIVE_VERSION', 'ubuntu_[vanilla|spark|cloudera|plain]_[hadoop_1|hadoop_2]_image_name', 'fedora_[vanilla|plain]_hadoop_[1|2]_image_name', 'centos_[vanilla|hdp|cloudera|plain]_[hadoop_1|hadoop_2]_image_name'. tox -e venv -- sahara-image-create -p [vanilla|spark|hdp|cloudera|storm|mapr|ambari|plain]You can create centos, ubuntu, fedora images without hadoop ('plain' image)
deleted_lines: This script builds Ubuntu, Fedora, CentOS cloud images for use in Sahara. By default the all plugin are targeted, all images will be built. The '-p' option can be used to select plugin (vanilla, spark, hdp or cloudera). The '-i' option can be used to select image type (ubuntu, fedora or centos). The '-v' option can be used to select hadoop version (1, 2 or plain).1. Use your environment (export / setenv) to alter the scripts behavior. Environment variables the script accepts are 'DIB_HADOOP_VERSION_1' and 'DIB_HADOOP_VERSION_2', 'JAVA_DOWNLOAD_URL', 'JAVA_TARGET_LOCATION', 'OOZIE_DOWNLOAD_URL', 'HIVE_VERSION', 'ubuntu_[vanilla|spark|cloudera]_[hadoop_1|hadoop_2]_image_name', 'fedora_vanilla_hadoop_[1|2]_image_name', 'centos_[vanilla|hdp|cloudera]_[hadoop_1|hadoop_2|plain]_image_name'. tox -e venv -- sahara-image-create -p [vanilla|spark|hdp|cloudera|storm|mapr|ambari]For HDP you can create only centos image with hadoop 1.3.0 or 2.0 and without hadoop ('plain' image). You shouldn't specify image type.

commit_message:
Move the content of CONTRIBUTING.rst to doc/source

When using cross reference across docs, it is easy to
handle them if the document itself in doc/source.
Otherwise, if we see CONTRIBUTING.rst in the top directory
directly, we cannot follow sphinx references.

Change-Id: I96b6cd24dcbf16e3923e4bc6fe4069d692e75993

added_lines: | expires | 2015-09-03T13:37:32Z | | id | 2542c427092a4b09a07ee7612c3d99ae | | tenant_id | c82e4bce56ce4cf9b90bd15dfdef699d | | user_id | 7f5becaaa38b4c9e850ccd11672a4c96 | $ export AUTH_TOKEN="2542c427092a4b09a07ee7612c3d99ae" $ export TENANT_ID="c82e4bce56ce4cf9b90bd15dfdef699d" Alternatively, if devstack environment is used, these values are available through "openrc" file under "devstack_install_root" directory and can be configured as: .. sourcecode:: console $ source <devstack_install_root>/openrc * Download and install a pre-built image with Ubuntu 14.04 $ wget http://sahara-files.mirantis.com/images/upstream/kilo/sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-ubuntu-14.04.qcow2 $ glance image-create --name=sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-ubuntu-14.04 \ --disk-format=qcow2 --container-format=bare < ./sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-ubuntu-14.04.qcow2 $ wget http://sahara-files.mirantis.com/images/upstream/kilo/sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-fedora-20.qcow2 $ glance image-create --name=sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-fedora-20 \ --disk-format=qcow2 --container-format=bare < ./sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-fedora-20.qcow2 $ glance image-list --name sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-ubuntu-14.04 | c119f99c-67f2-4404-9cff-f30e4b185036 | sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-ubuntu-14.04 | $ export IMAGE_ID="c119f99c-67f2-4404-9cff-f30e4b185036" $ sahara image-add-tag --id $IMAGE_ID --tag 2.7.1 +--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+----------+----------------+-------------+ | name | id | username | tags | description | +--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+----------+----------------+-------------+ | sahara-kilo-vanilla-2.6-ubuntu-14.04 | c119f99c-67f2-4404-9cff-f30e4b185036 | ubuntu | vanilla, 2.7.1 | None | +--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+----------+----------------+-------------+describe node group configurations. *Note, these templates assume that floating IP addresses are being used, for more details on Floating IP please see* :ref:`floating_ip_management` If your environment does not use Floating IP omit defining floating IP in below template. Sample templates can be found here: `Sample Templates <https://github.com/openstack/sahara/tree/master/sahara/plugins/default_templates/>`_ Create a file named ``my_master_template_create.json`` with the following "plugin_name": "vanilla", "hadoop_version": "2.7.1", "node_processes": [ "namenode", "resourcemanager", "hiveserver" ], "name": "vanilla-271-default-master", "floating_ip_pool": "public", "flavor_id": "2", "auto_security_group": true } Create a file named ``my_worker_template_create.json`` with the following { "plugin_name": "vanilla", "hadoop_version": "2.7.1", "node_processes": [ "nodemanager", "datanode" ], "name": "vanilla-271-default-worker", "floating_ip_pool": "public", "flavor_id": "2", "auto_security_group": true } $ sahara node-group-template-create --json my_master_template_create.json $ sahara node-group-template-create --json my_worker_template_create.json +----------------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+---------------------------------------+-------------+ | name | id | plugin_name | node_processes | description | +----------------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+---------------------------------------+-------------+ | vanilla-271-default-master | 9d3b5b2c-d5d5-4d16-8a93-a568d29c6569 | vanilla | namenode, resourcemanager, hiveserver | None | | vanilla-271-default-worker | 1aa4a397-cb1e-4f38-be18-7f65fa0cc2eb | vanilla | nodemanager, datanode | None | +----------------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+---------------------------------------+-------------+ used during cluster template creation. For example: * Master node group template id: ``9d3b5b2c-d5d5-4d16-8a93-a568d29c6569`` * Worker node group template id: ``1aa4a397-cb1e-4f38-be18-7f65fa0cc2eb``Create a file named ``my_cluster_template_create.json`` with the following { "plugin_name": "vanilla", "hadoop_version": "2.7.1", "node_groups": [ { "name": "worker", "count": 2, "node_group_template_id": "1aa4a397-cb1e-4f38-be18-7f65fa0cc2eb" }, { "name": "master", "count": 1, "node_group_template_id": "9d3b5b2c-d5d5-4d16-8a93-a568d29c6569" } ], "name": "vanilla-271-default-cluster", "cluster_configs": {} } $ sahara cluster-template-create --json my_cluster_template_create.json Save the cluster template id for use in the cluster provisioning command. The cluster id can be found in the output of the creation command or by listing the cluster templates as follows: +-----------------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------+-------------+ | name | id | plugin_name | node_groups | description | +-----------------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------+-------------+ | vanilla-271-default-cluster | 74add4df-07c2-4053-931f-d5844712727f | vanilla | master: 1, worker: 2 | None | +-----------------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------+-------------+Now you are ready to provision the cluster. This step requires a few pieces of information that can be found by querying various OpenStack services. Create a file named ``my_cluster_create.json`` with the following content: { "name": "my-cluster-1", "plugin_name": "vanilla", "hadoop_version": "2.7.1", "cluster_template_id" : "74add4df-07c2-4053-931f-d5844712727f", "user_keypair_id": "my_stack", "default_image_id": "c119f99c-67f2-4404-9cff-f30e4b185036", "neutron_management_network": "8cccf998-85e4-4c5f-8850-63d33c1c6916" } The parameter ``user_keypair_id`` with the value ``my_stack`` is generated by $ nova keypair-add my_stack --pub-key $PATH_TO_PUBLIC_KEY``my_cluster_create.json``. If your environment does not use neutron for example it uses nova-network, you can omit "neutron_management_network" above. You can determine the neutron network id with the following $ sahara cluster-create --json my_cluster_create.json +----------------------------+-------------------------------------------------+ | Run a MapReduce job to check Hadoop installation ---------------------------------------------------* Login to NameNode (usually master node) via ssh with ssh-key used above: $ ssh -i my_stack.pem ubuntu@<namenode_ip> $ cd /opt/hadoop-2.6.0/share/hadoop/mapreduce $ /opt/hadoop-2.6.0/bin/hadoop jar hadoop-mapreduce-examples-2.6.0.jar pi 10 100 Congratulations.! Now you have your Hadoop cluster ready on OpenStack cloud.

For example: * Master node group template id: ``b38227dc-64fe-42bf-8792-d1456b453ef3`` * Worker node group template id: ``634827b9-6a18-4837-ae15-5371d6ecf02c``Create a file named ``cluster_template_create.json`` with the following { "name": "demo-cluster-template", "plugin_name": "vanilla", "hadoop_version": "1.2.1", "node_groups": [ { "name": "master", "node_group_template_id": "b38227dc-64fe-42bf-8792-d1456b453ef3", "count": 1 }, { "name": "workers", "node_group_template_id": "634827b9-6a18-4837-ae15-5371d6ecf02c", "count": 2 } ] } $ sahara cluster-template-create --json cluster_template_create.json Save the template id for use in the cluster provisioning command. The cluster id can be found in the output of the creation command or by listing the cluster templates as follows: +-----------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+-----------------------+-------------+ | name | id | plugin_name | node_groups | description | +-----------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+-----------------------+-------------+ | demo-cluster-template | c0609da7-faac-4dcf-9cbc-858a3aa130cd | vanilla | master: 1, workers: 2 | None | +-----------------------+--------------------------------------+-------------+-----------------------+-------------+Now you will provision the cluster. This step requires a few pieces of information that will be found by querying various OpenStack services. Create a file named ``cluster_create.json`` with the following content: { "name": "cluster-1", "plugin_name": "vanilla", "hadoop_version": "1.2.1", "cluster_template_id" : "c0609da7-faac-4dcf-9cbc-858a3aa130cd", "user_keypair_id": "stack", "default_image_id": "3f9fc974-b484-4756-82a4-bff9e116919b" "neutron_management_network": "8cccf998-85e4-4c5f-8850-63d33c1c6916" } The parameter ``user_keypair_id`` with the value ``stack`` is generated by $ nova keypair-add stack --pub-key $PATH_TO_PUBLIC_KEY``cluster_create.json``. Cluster instances will get fixed IP addresses in this network. Now you have the Hadoop cluster ready on the OpenStack cloud.

Enterprise と openSUSE を使用" "した OpenStack ベースのクラウド用のイメージを構築できます。""するのに使用されますが、KVM イメージを構築するためにも使用できます。""<link xlink:href=\"https://packer.io\"> Packer</link> は、単一の設定ファイル" "ます。""を実行するために、以下の方法のどれかを使用します。""起動時にマウントされる、オプションの RAM ディスクファイル。Linux の場合、これ"msgstr "以下を前提としています。""existing system</guilabel> を選択します。インストールのプロンプトを 1 つずつ" "実行します。""qcow2 はスパースなので、qcow2 イメージは一般的に raw イメージより小さいです。" "イメージが小さいということは、アップロードが高速になるということを意味しま" "す。そのため、 raw ファイルをそのままアップロードする代わりに、アップロード用" "に raw イメージを qcow2 イメージに変換することがよくあります。""する場合、同じハイパーバイザーを使用する必要はありません。また、FreeBSD のデ""<literal>mirror.umd.edu</literal> の代わりに、他のミラーを使用することを考え" "てください。""る必要があります。インストーラーが URL だけを要求する場合、<literal>http://" "mirror.umd.edu/centos/6/os/x86_64</literal> は有効な URL の 1 つです。""作するように、以下の行を <filename>/boot/grub/menu.lst</filename> ファイルに" "追加する必要があるでしょう。""インスタンスがメタデータサービスにアクセスできるようにするために、デフォルト" "の zeroconf ルートを無効化する必要があります。"msgstr "インストーラーの ISO を取得します。""インストールに使用するデバイスの種類の確認が表示された場合、<guilabel>基本ス" "トレージデバイス (Basic Storage Devices)</guilabel> を選択します。""よくわからない場合、インストーラーのデフォルトのパーティション設定が最良であ" "るため、そのまま使用します。""\">cloud-init</link> パッケージを移植したものです。これが推奨の方法です。""のプラットフォームを使用する場合、イメージ作成時にそのプラットフォームを使用""これで、イメージを Image service にアップロードできます。今後は、この仮想マシ" "ンイメージは libvirt により管理する必要がありません。<placeholder-1/> コマン" "ドを使用して libvirt に通知します。""のコマンドを使用することもできますが、GUI を使用して、ディスクを切断し、手動" "で停止および起動を実行することもできます。""ACPI サービスをインストールし、システム起動時にサービスが起動するよう設定する" "ために、以下のコマンドを CentOS ゲスト内で実行します。""いくつかの VNC クライアントは、コロン (<literal>:</literal>) を クライアントを仮想マシンに接続してください。""な方法は、「基本サーバー (Basic Server)」インストールを選択することです " "(CentOS の古いバージョンでは、「サーバー (Server)」と呼んでいるかもしれませ" "ん)。SSH サーバーがインストールされます。"msgstr "スナップショットをサポートしています。""「raw」イメージ形式は最もシンプルな形式です。KVM ""録します。しかしながら、イメージが起動するたびに、仮想 Ethernet カードの " "MAC アドレスは別の値になります。そのため、この情報は設定ファイルから削除する" "必要があります。""上記のスクリプトは、メタデータサーバーから SSH 公開鍵のみを取得します。新しい" "インスタンスの要求時に、ユーザーが指定できるオプションデータである「ユーザー" を作成し、<literal>/</literal> にマウント" "したい場合もあるでしょう。これもうまく動作します。""削除など、さまざまなクリーンアップ作業を実行します。決まった場所にある仮想マ" "シンイメージをクリーンアップします。""application> プログラムは、独立してメンテナンスされており、活発に開発されてい" "ます。プロジェクトの現状に関する最良の情報源は <link xlink:href=\"http://" "pellaeon.github.io/bsd-cloudinit/\">http://pellaeon.github.io/bsd-cloudinit/" "</link> です。""対象にしています。CentOS のインストールプロセスはバージョンにより異なる可能性"msgstr "これは、上述の raw "コマンドを使用して、適切な接続先を確認できます。""スをインストールし実行しておく必要があります。""すべて実行してください。""簡単のため、「仮想マシンイメージ」の代わりに「イメージ」という言葉をときどき" "使用します。""リューションのことです。OpenStack ベースの Ubuntu Cloud Infrastructure により" "置き換えられました。"msgstr "cloud-init を使用した公開鍵の取得""仮想マシンイメージには、さまざまな形式があります。いくつかを以下に記載しま""ん。後ほど raw イメージを作成する方法については説明します。""前のアカウントに鍵を置くように、<systemitem class=\"service\">cloud-init</""インストールプロセスを高速化するために、メモリを最大で 1GB "github.io/bsd-cloudinit/\">http://pellaeon.github.io/bsd-cloudinit/</link> で" "す。""対象にしています。CentOS のインストールプロセスがバージョンにより異なる可能性"msgstr "これは、上に記載したような、raw 形式の仮想マシンイメージです。""<placeholder-1/> コマンドを使用して、ディスクを取り出すために、CD-ROM が前に" "接続されていた場所と同じ場所に、libvirt が空のディスクを接続する必要がありま" "す。この場所は、<literal>hdc</literal> でしょう。<placeholder-2/> コマンドを" "使用して、適切な接続先を確認できます。""スをインストールし、実行する必要があります。""完了します。""簡単にするために、「仮想マシンイメージ」の代わりに「イメージ」という言葉をと" "きどき使用します。""リューションを参照しています。これは、OpenStack ベースの Ubuntu Cloud " "Infrastructure により置き換えられました。"msgstr "公開鍵の取得のための coud-init の使用""仮想マシンイメージは、さまざまな形式があります。いくつかは以下に記載していま""ん。後ほど raw イメージを作成する方法について議論します。""前のアカウントに鍵を置くために、<systemitem class=\"service\">cloud-init</""インストールプロセスを高速化するために、メモリを 1GB まで指定できます。""ネットワークインストール ISO イメージが <filename>/data/isos</filename> に保" "存されています。"

commit_message:
Remove API_V3_CORE_EXTENSIONS from v2.1 API

We defined API_V3_CORE_EXTENSIONS as core Nova APIs.
If these core APIs are not loaded, the boot of nova-api failed.
However, now defcore team is trying to define core APIs and it is
not necessary to define them in Nova itself. In addition, we will
remove API extensions in long term. So now API_V3_CORE_EXTENSIONS
becomes meaningless.
This patch removes API_V3_CORE_EXTENSIONS for avoiding confusions
related to the API extensions.

Change-Id: I84ab02801c19aa3bf9509ff748f40716566ee9ff

commit_message:
Disable resize tests in Tempest if using cells with custom flavors

By default, devstack creates it's own test flavors for Tempest runs.

These are not in the cells API database since they are non-default
for nova so any resize tests in Tempest with cells and these custom
flavors fail.

Configure Tempest to not run resize tests if using cells and custom
flavors.

This allows us to also clean up a bunch of the resize skips found
in nova/devstack/tempest-dsvm-cells-rc.

Change-Id: I20f46024e45e32c60275703a193a56ae8cfe7eca
Closes-Bug: #1513925
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/92/242592/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ -z "$DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE" ]]; then # Cells supports resize but does not currently work with devstack # because of the custom flavors created for Tempest runs which are # not in the cells database. # TODO(mriedem): work on adding a nova-manage command to sync # flavors into the cells database. iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG compute-feature-enabled resize False fi

commit_message:
Add notes for account metadata

Change-Id: Ifb2b3edaa61b2f9275e92754c7c3b94b1b29a835
Closes-Bug: #1214136
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/48/241348/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
In Object Storage, account metadata operations work differently than container and object metadata operations work. Depending on the contents of a &POST; account metadata request, the Object Storage API updates account metadata in one of these ways:
Account metadata operations
POST request body contains Description
A metadata key without a value. The metadata key already exists for the account. The API removes the metadata item from the account.
A metadata key without a value. The metadata key does not already exist for the account. The API ignores the metadata key.
A metadata key value. The metadata key already exists for the account. The API updates the metadata key value for the account.
A metadata key value. The metadata key does not already exist for the account. The API adds the metadata key and value pair, or item, to the account.
One or more account metadata items are omitted. The metadata items already exist for the account. The API does not change the existing metadata items.
For these rules, specifying the X-Remove-Account-Meta-* request header for the key with any value is equivalent to specifying the X-Account-Meta-* request header with an empty value. Metadata keys must be treated as case-insensitive at all times, and can only contain ASCII 7-bit characters that are not control characters (0-31), and not DEL, and not a separator character according to HTTP/1.1. In addition, Object Storage does not support the underscore character, which it silently converts to a hyphen. The metadata values in Object Storage do not follow HTTP/1.1 rules for character encodings. In particular, you must use a UTF-8 encoding to get a byte array for any string that contains characters that do not fall into the 7-bit ASCII range (0-127). Otherwise, Object Storage returns the 404 response code for ISO-8859-1 characters in the 128-255 range, which is a direct violation of HTTP/1.1 §2.2.

commit_message:
Modify networking_config_agents for LBaas

Since there are some changes in section of Configure
Load-Balancer-as-a-Service (LBaaS), we updated content for both
haproxy and octavia backend references.This is for liberty release.

Closes-bug: #1500971
Change-Id: I6e9304fe2d9e3dabbce863f84a022a89704dd77b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/29/224929/41 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NEC, and NSX. At the backend side, user can use either haproxy or octavia, here we choose octavia as default option.#. Install octavia: .. code:: localrc # enable_plugin octavia https://github.com/openstack/octavia.git (For those who use haproxy as backend reference, you need to install the agent instead: ) the :file:`/etc/neutron/neutron_lbaas.conf` file: service_provider = LOADBALANCERV2:Octavia:neutron_lbaas. drivers.octavia.driver.OctaviaDriver:default(octavia) service_provider = LOADBALANCERV2:Haproxy:neutron_lbaas. drivers.haproxy.plugin_driver.HaproxyOnHostPluginDriver:default(haproxy) service_plugins = neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer.plugin. LoadBalancerPluginv2 service_plugins = neutron.services.l3_router.l3_router_plugin. L3RouterPlugin, neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer.plugin.LoadBalancerPluginv2
deleted_lines: NEC, and NSX.#. Install the agent: the :file:`/etc/neutron/neutron.conf` file: service_provider = LOADBALANCER:Haproxy:neutron_lbaas.services loadbalancer.drivers.haproxy.plugin_driver.HaproxyOnHostPluginDriver :default service_plugins = lbaas service_plugins = router,lbaas #. Enable the HAProxy load balancer in the :file:`/etc/neutron/lbaas_agent.ini` file: .. code:: ini device_driver = neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer.drivers haproxy.namespace_driver.HaproxyNSDriver

commit_message:
swift flags: read from RST

The extract_swift_flags.py script parses the existing docbook tables to
discover documented options. We're now switching to RST so implement
reading from RST tables, and make it the default behaviour.

Implements: blueprint config-ref-rst
Change-Id: Ib7a14cc52337fc1abd8b02a8ff33396c0b992746

commit_message:
[install] Fix various minor problems

Fix the following minor problems to reduce work after
stable/liberty branching:

1) RDO: Revert Python MySQL library from PyMySQL to MySQL-python
   due to lack of support for the former.
2) RDO: Explicitly install 'ebtables' and 'ipset' packages due
   to dependency problems.
3) General: Change numbered list to bulleted list for lists with
   only one item.
4) General: Restructure horizon content to match other services.
   More duplication of content, but sometimes RST conditionals
   are terrible and distro packages should use the same
   configuration files.
5) General: Restructure NoSQL content to match SQL content.
6) General: Improve clarity of NTP content.

Change-Id: I2620250aa27c7d41b525aa2646ad25e0692140c4
Closes-Bug: #1514760
Closes-Bug: #1514683
Implements: bp installguide-liberty

commit_message:
Remove multi-region workaround

When keystone API v3 was introduced, filtering regions when listing
endpoints was not supported (see [1]). This caused multi-region devstack
deployments to fail (see [2]). A workaround was introduced to devstack
to enable for multi-region deployments until region filtering would work
in keystone API v3.
Now that the bug related to region filtering in keystone is resolved,
the workaround should be removed.

[1]: https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1482772
[2]: https://bugs.launchpad.net/devstack/+bug/1483784

Closes-Bug: #1511745
Related-Bug: #1483784
Related-Bug: #1482772
Change-Id: I52d13c3f5e7b77a7f8fb1be4dcea437988ebddfe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/49/240549/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # TODO(dgonzalez): The check of the region name, as done in the grep # statement below, exists only because keystone does currently # not allow filtering the region name when listing endpoints. If keystone # gets support for this, the check for the region name can be removed. # Related bug in keystone: https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1482772 -c ID -c Region -f value | grep $4 | cut -f 1 -d " ")

commit_message:
upgrade.rst: Fix v2 plugin history

Actually Kilo had v2 plugin.
(I misremembered that it was introduced by Liberty.)

Also, stop using stevedore aliases in examples as they are
not available for these releases.

Change-Id: I4bcf81535a754cd1ea229846618f522c10323785

commit_message:
Remove 'enable_service tempest' from sample/local.conf

tempest is already defined in stackrc as default.
Without this definition in local.conf,
tempest is installed successfully.

If it still needs "enable_service tempest" definition
on local.conf,
devstack itself has some problem.
In my environment, tempest installation works
without this definition on local.conf.

Change-Id: I25cda0142538d21bb9656b471e65ca5b018e8378

subject: Cleanup ReST format issues
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-02 10:28:57.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/guides/neutron.rst', 'doc/source/guides/devstack-with-lbaas-v2.rst', 'doc/source/configuration.rst', 'doc/source/guides/devstack-with-nested-kvm.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/c30657d7de1a253ffd541d07a0b449d395cb8eab', 'message': 'Cleanup ReST format issues

* ReST doesn't allow monospace in italic sections.
      bash$ grep -R \`\` doc/build/html/ --include "*.html"
* The code-block section "::" needed an empty line before the code,
  otherwise it gets shown in the HTML output.
      bash$ egrep -R "<dt>::" doc/build/html/ --include "*.html"
* Monospaced font incorrectly marked with a single back tick
      bash$ egrep -nR '\w`(\s|[\.,;:])' doc/source/ --include "*.rst"

Change-Id: I66c3f685f33851c3f3f0f859996037fc24930246
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup ReST format issues

* ReST doesn't allow monospace in italic sections.
      bash$ grep -R \`\` doc/build/html/ --include "*.html"
* The code-block section "::" needed an empty line before the code,
  otherwise it gets shown in the HTML output.
      bash$ egrep -R "<dt>::" doc/build/html/ --include "*.html"
* Monospaced font incorrectly marked with a single back tick
      bash$ egrep -nR '\w`(\s|[\.,;:])' doc/source/ --include "*.rst"

Change-Id: I66c3f685f33851c3f3f0f859996037fc24930246

commit_message:
Update instructions to generate GMR error reports

Guru Meditation Reports (GMR) code in oslo.reports was recently updated
to expect SIGUSR2 as opposed to SIGUSR1, because it is reserved by
Apache 'mod_wsgi' for its own use.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/223133/ -- guru_meditation_report:
    Use SIGUSR2 instead of SIGUSR1

Change-Id: I4dbf1a11d3737c4a8444b3a79de824acecb56d7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/88/241588/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: A *GMR* can be generated by sending the *USR2* signal to any Heat process with support (see below). The *GMR* will then be outputted standard error for that particular process. For example, suppose that ``heat-api`` has process id ``10172``, and was run with ``2>/var/log/heat/heat-api-err.log``. Then, ``kill -USR2 10172`` will trigger the Guru Meditation report to be printed to ``/var/log/heat/heat-api-err.log``.
deleted_lines: A *GMR* can be generated by sending the *USR1* signal to any Heat process with support (see below). The *GMR* will then be outputted standard error for that particular process. For example, suppose that ``heat-api`` has process id ``10172``, and was run with ``2>/var/log/heat/heat-api-err.log``. Then, ``kill -USR1 10172`` will trigger the Guru Meditation report to be printed to ``/var/log/heat/heat-api-err.log``.

[WIP] Disabling users/groups invalidating tokens

OSSN-0050
__________________
< Work In Progress >
 ------------------
        \   ^__^
         \  (oo)\_______
            (__)\       )\/\
                ||----w |
                ||     ||

Closes-Bug: 1434034
Signed-off-by: Dave Walker (Daviey) <email@daviey.com>
Change-Id: I93e28184c391426f488af66e5e404efaaf905195
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/03/200303/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Disabling users & groups may not invalidate previously issued tokens --- ### Summary ### When keystone users or groups are disabled outside of keystone API's, tokens are not invalidated and can continue to be used until expiration. Whilst this isn't considered a vulnerability by the OpenStack Vulnerability Management team, it is felt appropriate to create an OpenStack Security Notice to raise awareness of this known behaviour. ### Affected Services / Software ### keystone (all releases), also any additional services relying upon keystone tokens for authorisation. ### Discussion ### When users or groups are disabled through the keystone API the already issued tokens are invalidated by keystone itself. However, users and groups may be managed externally of Keystone such as: - LDAP (or AD) Identity provider. - Federation IdP - Private Key Infrastructure (PKI) - Direct SQL updates to the database. Unlike disabling using keystone API's, these above mechanisms do not have a revocation procedure. This is a limited issue to situations such as when a user is disabled outside of keystone. Keystone is not informed that the user was disabled because no API call was made to disable the user via keystone, which would usually invalidate already issued tokens. Whilst it is possible for Keystone to add additional validation for the identify providers of LDAP and SQL, this cannot be achieved with the Federation extension, as the user is required to be in the path for SAML assertions and this cannot be possible at token validation time. In addition, this cannot be solved in a robust way to solve this for PKI due to signed datasets. This means that this mechanism is at a disadvantage compared to uuid/Fernet tokens. However, the exposure is limited to deferring the invalidation until the declared expiry lifetime of the token. Keystone configuration has the default token expiration value of 3600 seconds (1 hour), which is usually an acceptable risk for most deployments. Based on feedback it seems that many deployments increase the time-to-live (ttl) of the token from the default of 3600 seconds up to 86400 seconds because the default was insufficient for some operations, specifically glance and cinder actions. ### Recommended Actions ### This issue has not yet been resolved for any of the Identity services, but it is expected that LDAP and SQL will receive remediation shortly. To help reduce weakness surface (and general hardening), it is recommended to reduce the [token] expiration to a value that is an acceptable risk for your deployment, or keep it at the current default of 3600 seconds (1 hour). ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0050 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://launchpad.net/bugs/1434034 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg

commit_message:
Detach iSCSI latest path for latest disk

The logic responsible to disconnect iscsi volumes wasn't clearing
latest path for the latest remaining disk. With this change,
latest disk path is removed right before iscsi disk is disconnected.

Also, the device descriptor was not removed if the iqn are different
and multipath is enabled.

Change-Id: Ib6f6cea40cc3a14a3a443b157d0decba5602bf13
Closes-Bug: 1374999
Closes-Bug: 1452032

commit_message:
Update neutron-debug to use stevedore aliases

Updating neutron-debug as it is importing interface driver classes
directly and not using the load_driver_interface method.
Also adds unit tests for the neutron-debug tool.

Change-Id: Icf095b2182225e63e85d849d83c2cb36b8a39217
Closes-Bug: #1504536

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. _image_guide_rst: =========================================== Virtual Machine Image Guide: RST conversion =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+spec/image-guide-rst Convert the Virtual Machine Image Guide from DocBook to RST. Problem description =================== The Virtual Machine Image Guide will be converted from DocBook to RST for the Mitaka release. Proposed change =============== Convert the Virtual Machine Image Guide to RST. Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * kato-tomoyuki Work Items ---------- * Ensure bug fix proposals are included in DocBook and RST during the conversion process. * Track changes in wiki_. .. _wiki: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Migrate * Update our build infrastructure so that Sphinx is used for publishing the Virtual Machine Image Guide. * Apply the openstackdocstheme template to the guide. Dependencies ============ The main dependency is on docs.openstack.org infrastructure updates. Testing ======= * Test the new HTML design on the following browsers/operating systems: * Chrome on Ubuntu, Fedora, Mac, Windows * Firefox on Ubuntu, Fedora, Mac, Windows References ========== * Discussion can occur using any official medium including IRC in #openstack-doc, the openstack-docs mailing list with [image-guide] in the subject, weekly `documentation team meeting`_, and potentially etherpads. .. _`documentation team meeting`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/DocTeamMeeting * `Migration wiki`_ .. _`Migration wiki`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Migrate

added_lines: ========== Multi-site ========== OpenStack is capable of running in a multi-region configuration. This enables some parts of OpenStack to effectively manage a group of sites as a single cloud. Some use cases that might indicate a need for a multi-site deployment of OpenStack include: - An organization with a diverse geographic footprint. - Geo-location sensitive data. - Data locality, in which specific data or functionality should be close to users. .. toctree:: :maxdepth: 2 multi_site/section_user_requirements_multi_site.rst multi_site/section_tech_considerations_multi_site.rst multi_site/section_operational_considerations_multi_site.rst multi_site/section_architecture_multi_site.rst multi_site/section_prescriptive_examples_multi_site.rst

commit_message:
Enable "openstack server lock" command to take multiple servers.

Current "openstack server lock" command could only lock one server.
Improve it to be able to handle more than one servers. Also improve
the doc to reflect the new feature.

Change-Id: Ifcf103b1c32e6c547ac09f688b887b1c03f92b09
Implements: blueprint cmd-with-multi-servers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/17/244417/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Lock server(s). A non-admin user will not be able to execute actions""" nargs='+', help=_('Server(s) to lock (name or ID)'), for server in parsed_args.server: utils.find_resource( compute_client.servers, server, ).lock()
deleted_lines: """Lock a server. A non-admin user will not be able to execute actions""" help=_('Server (name or ID)'), utils.find_resource( compute_client.servers, parsed_args.server, ).lock()

commit_message:
Save functional testing files after testing done.

Save functional_creds.conf and functional-tests.log for further debugging.

Closes-Bug: #1516466
Change-Id: Ie4f7697c865596fe0479a3aa6c9ace2f0b12eb3d

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ================================ Add microversions tests for Nova ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/nova-microversions-tests In Kilo cycle, microversions has been implemented in Nova. Clients can specify microversion with request header "X-OpenStack-Nova-API- Version", and Nova returns a response which is different between microversions. This blueprint proposes to add microversions tests for Nova. Problem description =================== A detailed description of the problem. Proposed change =============== Here is where you cover the change you propose to make in detail. How do you propose to solve this problem? If this is one part of a larger effort make it clear where this piece ends. In other words, what's the scope of this effort? Include where in the tempest tree hierarchy this will reside. If the change is designed to test other OpenStack projects then list which ones it is targeted at. Alternatives ------------ This is an optional section which applies if the blueprint covers infrastructure changes to tempest. For example, blueprints which are just adding more API tests can leave this section empty. Where it does apply we'd just like a demonstration that some thought has been put into why the proposed approach is the best one. Projects ======== List the qa projects that this spec effects. For example: * openstack/tempest * openstack/tempest-lib * openstack-dev/devstack Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Can optionally can list additional ids if they intend on doing substantial implementation work on this blueprint. Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno-1 Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ - Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in tempest, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. - Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library?

commit_message:
Fix SDK exception message parse

Currently the error message of SDK exception is not
well parsed, this patch fixed it to make the error
message contain more information to user.

Change-Id: I804893aca4ce03ca3630be0644043ce0ca689621
Closes-Bug: #1515108

commit_message:
Resource.has_interface check get_resource_info result

This changes the behaviour of has_interface to not assume that
get_resource_info always returns a type. There are circumstances when it
won't, such as when the type is no longer in the new registry during a
stack update.

Change-Id: Idd9dade85d105dc6839ff0740e6c80aca6b7ad9f
Closes-Bug: #1509880
(cherry picked from commit af3355d34c8b8e4030f7a928a6c7cb9ad70e0795)

Allow to specify branch for creating new migration

Add options to 'neutron-db-manage revision' command for specifying
a branch.

DocImpact

commit_message:
py3: Fix error handling in prophetstor driver

* Port prophetstor driver to Python 3
* Replace "except exception as e:" with "except Exception as e:"
  to handle "Fexvisor failed to join the volume ..." and "Fexvisor
  failed to remove the volume ..." errors. Here, lower case
  "exception" is the cinder.exception module, not an exception class.
  On Python 3, "except" requires exception classes.
* tests-py3.txt: add cinder.tests.unit.test_prophetstor_dpl

Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-python3
Change-Id: I0447b62cc0afe5a10ecbc888dfb6608b69f977d2

commit_message:
Enable "openstack server unpause" command to take multiple servers.

Current "openstack server unpause" command could only unpause one server.
Improve it to be able to handle more than one servers. Also improve the
doc to reflect the new feature.

Change-Id: I069ebdd6dcd121f6e55c2bf40d42197f93830e0c
Implements: blueprint cmd-with-multi-servers

deleted_lines: """Unpause server""" help=_('Server (name or ID)'), utils.find_resource( compute_client.servers, parsed_args.server, ).unpause()

commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Remove TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR in the api tox env""

This reverts commit a3154b03ac60df586bd8fd67f03c20327f2dde41.

The revert was merged too quickly, without waiting for tox project to fix us.
The gate passed for the revert only because infra folks removed images
that had new tox in them. We will be broken by the next images though.

(cherry picked from commit be63289c273fa02159a6958e0b456d5fda217431)

Conflicts:
	tox.ini
Change-Id: I148c80e5b9512fee280ecbf3ca7498ddf1cfd96d

commit_message:
Extract json encoding to utils

Caching data and other things are going to require json encoding now so
extract this method out to the utils file.

Change-Id: If1ee2e04c10812afe7d9521f7c5a0ae036fa8b1c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth refs/changes/11/245611/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import jsonimport uuidtry: import netaddr except ImportError: netaddr = None class _JSONEncoder(json.JSONEncoder): def default(self, o): if isinstance(o, datetime.datetime): return o.isoformat() if isinstance(o, uuid.UUID): return six.text_type(o) if netaddr and isinstance(o, netaddr.IPAddress): return six.text_type(o) return super(_JSONEncoder, self).default(o) def jsonencode(data): return _JSONEncoder().encode(data)

commit_message:
Correct set the default value for min_size/max_size

If min_size/max_size is passed as none, then they will store as
None in db, this patch will correctly set the default values for
them.

Change-Id: I9a25846709a8618249ee47ce40cdd7c89cce9bd1
Closes-Bug: #1515134
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/11/245011/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
StackUser tolerate missing user on delete

If a stack domain user is missing on delete, we currently fail to
delete the keypair.  We should tolerate this in a simiar way to
that done for _delete_user.

Change-Id: I6d60612e6187385a2d3b6b6fcf67acb99b572fc3
Closes-Bug: #1505981
(cherry picked from commit 730ccc5abf6dd5e133578b4b7fbef32e3b64fe14)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/69/242269/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except kc_exception.NotFound: pass

subject: Implement monitoring port changes by port status message
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-20 06:38:04.000000000', 'files': ['networking_ofagent/plugins/ofagent/agent/monitor.py', 'networking_ofagent/plugins/ofagent/agent/ofa_neutron_agent.py', 'networking_ofagent/tests/unit/ofagent/test_monitor.py', 'networking_ofagent/tests/unit/ofagent/test_ofa_neutron_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ofagent/commit/cffbcc1e68029ef3ae7c556f05113760697692ff', 'message': 'Implement monitoring port changes by port status message

Currently ofagent is monitoring port changes comparing current
and last information got from port description.
The new port monitoring catches port changes using port status
message. This will be useful in the following point.
- This can avoid a vain request of port description.
- The old port monitoring may drop port changes in a case of
  continuous operation deleting and adding a port with same name.
  The new port monitoring can catch all port changes which occur
  between polling interval using port status message.

Change-Id: I856cb35652db239828131c7e10a100534696869d
'}]
commit_message:
Implement monitoring port changes by port status message

Currently ofagent is monitoring port changes comparing current
and last information got from port description.
The new port monitoring catches port changes using port status
message. This will be useful in the following point.
- This can avoid a vain request of port description.
- The old port monitoring may drop port changes in a case of
  continuous operation deleting and adding a port with same name.
  The new port monitoring can catch all port changes which occur
  between polling interval using port status message.

Change-Id: I856cb35652db239828131c7e10a100534696869d

commit_message:
Add additional filter to volume_type check

Adding extra filter in volumes_type check
as a workaround until the issue in cinder
will be fixed.

Related-bug: 1508102
Closes-bug: 1508017
(cherry picked from commit 251b86b3f676817b9797788de20faaacb8a954d7)

Fixing problem with validation of job binaries update

Job binary can't be updated without url changing

Closes-bug: #1508507
(cherry picked from commit b0b5556a4609cc29dbd1d1a957229fd63481a29d)

commit_message:
Make ssh timeout configurable

Added config option in sahara.conf to enable configurable
timeouts for ssh connections.

Change-Id: Ib0c0ac92229df387a0a5b0474c38af67e5312d2a
Closes-bug: 1506668
(cherry picked from commit 8a43bc1664571ba4bf771bc8ebceab595c760cbb)

commit_message:
Missing stuff for Kafka in Ambari plugin

Open ports for Kafka Broker (default 6667) and also
open port for ZooKeeper (default 2181).

Change-Id: Ifabdcfa295de03a2b1a120bf291c7b876948e921
Closes-bug: 1512661
(cherry picked from commit 08fb1b8ce64d39b1a101e3c4a6074047e1ec578c)

commit_message:
Fix cinder objects unit test registration

The base test case was extending test code from oslo_versionedobjects
which is bad because (1) it was adding test objects from the o.vo
registry into the cinder object registry and (2) it was extending
internal private test classes from o.vo which are subject to change and
would break cinder.

This cleans up the base test case and object registration to basically
do it the same way that nova does.

It also moves the duplicate _compare() method into the base class and
fixes a bug where db obj fields that were lists were compared
incorrectly against object lists.

This will allow us to verify object version hashes using o.vo's
ObjectVersionChecker fixture in a follow on change without the
extraneous object registrations from o.vo messing with the results.

Partial-Bug: #1514926

Change-Id: Ie34675e378951cda9aa218f3181dc86767717450
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/68/243868/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: @staticmethod def _compare(test, db, obj): for field, value in db.items(): test.assertEqual(db[field], obj[field])

commit_message:
Fix Quorum rules

Closes-bug: #1484116

Change-Id: I9e0dc67a72ba25520495c75c630833f30f20b87b
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ha-guide refs/changes/18/225418/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: have an odd number of nodes and the quorum must specify more than a halfFor example, in a 7-node cluster, the quorum should be set to 7/2+1=4. If quorum is 4 and four nodes fail simultaneously,whereas it would continue to function if no more than 3 nodes fail, or if the quorum were set to 3 (although that is not recommended and would likely cause a split-brain). When split to partitions of 3 and 4 nodes respectively, the quorum of 4 nodes would continue to operate the majority partition and stop or fence the minority one (depends on the cluster configuration). That is why the quorum of 3 would have been a bad choise, making both partitions to operate as independent clusters (a split-brain).
deleted_lines: have an odd number of nodes and the quorum must specify an odd numberFor example, in a 7-node cluster, the quorum could be set to 5 or 3. If quorum is 5 and three nodes fail simultaneously,whereas it would continue to function if the quorum were set to 3.

commit_message:
Refactor HP 3PAR drivers to now be HPE

This patch refactors the HP 3PAR FC and iSCSI drivers to be
HPE 3PAR FC and HPE 3PAR iSCI.

This is being done because the company responsible for the
HP 3PAR FC and iSCSI drivers is now called Hewlett Packard
Enterprise (HPE).

The drivers are now located in the cinder/volume/drivers/hpe
folder.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rebrand-hp-3par-driver
Change-Id: I529429e00ef5e1b7263d40d9d50ed8ac8535d34a

commit_message:
Add ability to get endpoints from catalog

The barbican plugin requires both the barbican and the keystone
endpoint. Since these are generally in the catalog, we can get them from
there rather than requiring them to be hard-coded.

Change-Id: I926547d2d95b3c59a849c1796342a11cc41b73cc

commit_message:
Add complementary explanation for <host> format of cinder migrate

From Juno, Pool-aware scheduler was introduced. As a result,
destination format of "migrate" and "manage" commands were changed
as it included pool name like host@backend-name#pool-name.

This patch changes help string of "migrate" to explain more detail
of <host> format to avoid a confusion for users.
Help string of "manage" command already shows detailed <host> format.

Now the latest community document explains this command with
pool-name format.
We also need to update help message of command line.

http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/blockstorage_volume_migration.html

Partial-Bug: 1403902
Change-Id: If984aeb3a8f8f55e1e97cfac43f8866e63d6bb14
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/64/145064/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Modify URI for endpoints and ipsecsiteconnections

This commit fixes the following VPNaaS URIs:

  * /v2.0/vpn/endpointgroups to /v2.0/vpn/endpoint-groups
  * /v2.0/vpn/ipsecsiteconnections to /v2.0/vpn/ipsec-site-connections

Change-Id: I0bf4fe34e78119119ede896d37a4b7a8dc58f5d9
Closes-Bug: #1515465

commit_message:
Replace attach_ip_to_server() with add_ip_list()

In later versions of shade, attach_ip_to_server() has been
deprecated and is now a private function. Changed each call
of that function to add_ip_list().

Change-Id: I2dcd0699b3969a03d43d794f156bdc48e213deff

commit_message:
Remove os-pci API in Nova v2.1 API ref

os-pci is not supported, should be removed.

(df) removed os-pci extension from os-hypervisors-v2.1.wadl
(df) updated os-hypervisors calls to show correct examples

Change-Id: I38663fe404ba173a6d85319cd59d228016ab47bd
Closes-Bug: #1514314

commit_message:
Add three pieces of the Session interface

In trying to use betamax with a keystoneauth1 Session, which interacts
by mounting itself as an adapter, it became clear that our wrapping of
requests.Session was incomplete in that regard. Adding an adapters
property with a setter and a mount method worked and betamax is now
totally usable with keystoneauth1.session.

Closes-Bug:#1516382
Change-Id: I1ebc4a726bb516349714e55eb97b384ed40b42cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth refs/changes/30/245530/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @property def adapters(self): return self.session.adapters @adapters.setter def adapters(self, value): self.session.adapters = value def mount(self, scheme, adapter): self.session.mount(scheme, adapter)

commit_message:
Specify default_domain to generic plugin

The generic plugin is supposed to work with both the v2 and v3 APIs.
This doesn't necessarily work because you either need to provide domain
information or not which implies specifying a v2 or v3 preference.

By adding default domain we can allow using v2 or v3 authentication
interchangeably. This is something that openstackclient does already.

Closes-Bug: #1515041
Change-Id: I8d036a080a09b9310ffdd73d3501b6df29a212b9

commit_message:
Add profiling support to OpenStack client

To be able to create profiling traces for Zaqar and Glance,
client should be able to send special HTTP header that contains
trace info. This patch is as well important to be able to make
cross project traces. (Typical case end user calls Zaqar or other
service like Glance via OpenStack python client, if profiler is
initialized, Zaqar and Glance client will add extra header, that
will be parsed by special osprofiler middleware at server side)

Don't worry no security issue here, trace information is signed
by HMAC key that is setted in config file at server side. So only
person that knows HMAC key is able to send proper header.

Zaqar server patch is: I32565de6c447cd5e95a0ef54a9fbd4e571c2d820
Zaqar client patch is: I880c003511e9e4ef99806ba5b19d0ef6996be80b

Currently there are some projects are using osprofiler, like Glance, 
Cinder, Heat, and some others are working in progress, e.g. Trove.

Change-Id: I8779d771a73ec51cea0603f2f57ac36433f06eb4
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

added_lines: from oslo.utils import importutilsosprofiler_profiler = importutils.try_import("osprofiler.profiler") finally: if osprofiler_profiler: profiler = osprofiler_profiler.get() if profiler: # Initialized by --profile argument trace_id = profiler.get_base_id() print("Profiling trace ID: %s" % trace_id) print("To display trace use next command:\n" "osprofiler trace show --html %s " % trace_id) if osprofiler_profiler: parser.add_argument('--profile', metavar='HMAC_KEY', help='HMAC key to use for encrypting context ' 'data for performance profiling of operation. ' 'This key should be the value of HMAC key ' 'configured in osprofiler middleware at ' 'server side, it is specified in main or ' 'paste configuration file. Without key the ' 'profiling will not be triggered even if ' 'osprofiler is enabled on server side.') # Initialize profiler if osprofiler_profiler and self.options.profile: osprofiler_profiler.init(self.options.profile)

commit_message:
Add shell --profile option to trigger osprofiler

This patch add new option --profile that will trigger osprofiler
(tracing) from CLI.

So if you have installed osprofiler lib. And you type
openstack --profile SECRET_KEY user list

At the end of output there will be message with <trace_id>
to plot nice HTML graphs use command:

osprofiler trace show <trace_id> --html --out result.html

Related patch:
(keystone) https://review.openstack.org/#/c/103368/
(glance)   https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105635/
(nova)     https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105096/

Change-Id: Ia5a168cdb2cdd316b2341ae9753957e16af87c0a

commit_message:
launch_instance: remove wrong ERROR label

Having to try more than once before the instance responds to a ping
should not be classified as an error.

A small refactoring simplifies the code somewhat.

Change-Id: Id06efa88e88c29687d03d84329c099e86c7bc538

commit_message:
Fix RetryFilter error

This patch allows launch_instance to succeed in some cases where
launching an instance would repeatedly fail because the RetryFilter
returns 0 hosts.

The error occurs frequently after a cluster build with the kilo scripts.
The patch fixes the problem by restarting nova-compute.

Change-Id: I74b78e6ecc70f51d00da010c10f98ff46f702af8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-labs refs/changes/24/245424/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if sudo comm -13 /tmp/nova-scheduler.log $NOVA_SCHED_LOG | grep "Filter RetryFilter returned 0 hosts"; then echo "SUM ERROR RetryFilter returned 0 hosts" show_compute_resource_usage echo "Restarting nova-compute on compute node." ssh_no_chk_node compute-mgmt \ sudo service nova-compute restart NOVA_COMPUTE_RESTART=$((${NOVA_COMPUTE_RESTART:-0} + 1)) fi

code to avoid potential typos.

commit_message:
Introduce address scopes

ApiImpact

Change-Id: I2c75f7ef74fea4f659436c32da8feab88f9e4153
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/67/180267/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============== Address Scopes ============== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/address-scopes Let's make address scopes a first class thing in Neutron. With all of the overlapping and arbitrary use of the both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses it is impossible for Neutron to know what can be routed where. Address scopes will be used by Neutron to address this problem. This proposal has no relation to RFC 4007 IPv6 address scopes [#]_. If you can come up with a better name for this than "address scopes" to avoid ambiguity, please suggest it here as a comment. .. [#] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4007 Problem Description =================== Neutron allows overlapping IP addresses. Before Kilo, a subnet could be created with any cidr the user wanted to supply. It didn't matter if the address overlapped with another subnet in the same project or another project. Neutron provides isolation at the L2 level to ensure this can work. Subnet Pools [#]_ added in Kilo are a step in the right direction. They add overlap protection and allow an admin to define a pool of addresses from which subnets can be allocated by multiple projects. Now we can coordinate addresses. This is good. Neutron L3 provides a limited routing solution to isolate between projects. As long as routers only connect one project's internal networks, floating ips will work it out between projects. But, this is easily broken. A project could attempt routing between two internal networks with the same subnet address. If routers are plugged in to shared networks, things could get uglier. With IPv6, we want to forget floating IPs and route straight in to tenant networks. We can't just turn on routing assuming that everything will just work. How can we tell the difference between a valid, unique, and globally routable subnet and one that someone just made up while filling out the subnet create details? Also, the full integration of MPLS/BGP VPN in to Neutron has been blocked by this. An analog to address scopes in the L3 VPN world are route distinguishers. With the addition of address scopes, we can easily map to route distinguishers. This work is not in scope for this blueprint but will be further enabled by it. .. [#] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/subnet-allocation Proposed Change =============== Add a new object called AddressScope. An AddressScope can be associated with multiple SubnetPool objects in a one-to-many relationship. This will allow delegating parts of an address scope to different tenants. The SubnetPools under an AddressScope must not overlap. Only an admin can associate an AddressPool and SubnetPool from different tenants. A SubnetPool which is not associated with an AddressScope will be considered alone in its own address scope. The id of the subnet pool will be used as the id of the address scope. .. TODO I imagine that most cases will associate one to one. However, I don't want to conflate the two. Maybe we could initially only allow one to one and just use the subnetpool id as the id. IOW, maybe we could conflate the two initially and add the new data model/api as extra credit. Neutron routers will be aware of address scopes. The reference L3 implementation will use multiple routing tables and policy routing to implement connecting to networks with different address scopes. Both the incoming device (iif) and the subnet prefix will be specified with each rule. .. TODO What happens if there are multiple subnets on a network from different address scopes. This can happen today. The source and destination addresses can't be used to distiguish the address scope because they may have nothing to do with the subnets on the link; they may have been forwarded to/from somewhere else. The incoming interface can't be used because it is ambiguous. Subnets on a network will be constrained to the same address scope [#]_. .. [#] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1451559 .. TODO Would it be better to constrain them to the same pool? It could get really complicated when pools can be associated with different scopes. What if a pool changes scope and this leaves some networks with mixed scopes? Data Model Impact ----------------- TODO(Carl) Flesh out the details here. #. Adds a new table for address scopes. #. Adds a new field (default null) to the SubnetPool referencing a single AddressScope. REST API Impact --------------- TODO(Carl) Flesh out the details here. Basically, we add CRUD semantics for the new address scope object. This includes a field for associated subnet pools. Security Impact --------------- See the performance impact. A change in an address scope could have a big impact on the control plane. Notifications Impact -------------------- TODO: Notifications to routers on... #. Create/Update/Delete of Address Scopes sends an update for routers connected to affected subnets. The scope of any subnet belonging to a subnet pool can be changed. #. RPC data for a router sent to the L3 agent will be enhanced by adding the address scope ID of each subnet a router connects to. It think this should be sent with the port. Other End User Impact --------------------- #. The python-neutron client will be enhanced to operate on address scopes Performance Impact ------------------ The addition, deletion, or update or AddressScopes could result in a lot of L3 agent activity. This is because any change in address pools can change the scope of a subnet. Any changes involving more than one project will be an admin only operation which should limit the concern here. In any case, it shouldn't have any bigger impact than deploying a software upgrade which would restart L3 agents. .. TODO consider making address scopes admin-only? When an L3 agent requests information about a router, the address scope of each of the subnets to which the router is connected must be looked up. This can be done without adding any new queries. Existing queries will need to join the address scope table on the subnet pool id to retrieve the address scope id. IPv6 Impact ----------- This will work for IPv4 and IPv6 equally as well. Some might argue that we don't need this for IPv6 because everyone will have unique addresses. But, they're missing the point because this isn't just about solving the problem of overlapping IPv4 addresses. It also recognizes that we have tenants choosing IPv6 addresses too. They could overlap or not be routable for other reasons. We're giving Neutron the ability to know how to handle them. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- The community will love it. ;) Seriously though, this allows Neutron L3 to know where stuff can be routed. This is important especially with IPv6 where we want to just route through to project's networks instead of using floating IPs to traverse the address scope boundary. It is also an important piece to integrating MPLS/VPN which has been requested countless times from the community. This work will be integrated with the BGP work after that work has matured a bit. BGP and other dynamic routing protocols will be address scope aware so that only addresses from the right scope are advertised to a given peer or on a given network. Alternatives ------------ There are alternatives to using multiple routing tables and policy routing. For example, iptables rules could be attempted but may not be able to address all cases, especially if addresses overlap. Address scopes map very nicely on to multiple routing tables and routing policy. It is the perfect fit. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: `carl-baldwin <https://launchpad.net/~carl-baldwin>`_ Other contributors: Volunteers? Work Items ---------- #. Add address scope id to RPC response to L3 agent. (Initially just the subnet pool id) #. Enhance L3 agent to honer address scopes in routing tables and policy routing. #. Add DB model for address scopes #. Add CRUD for AddressScope, including association with SubnetPool. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None Functional Tests ---------------- Functional testing of the L3 agent enhancements to the routing tables. API Tests --------- Full API test coverage of the new API. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ This feature deserves some new user documentation for how/why to use the new API. Developer Documentation ----------------------- New API to be documented. References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/subnet-allocation
