subject: WIP - Add Group Based Policy Project
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-05 21:22:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/51d18ca01a45fba9a1dcf8408bfdcfe5669a826e', 'message': 'Add Group Based Policy Project

Group Based Policy (GBP) [1] is a policy framework consisting of declarative,
intent-based abstractions for cloud infrastructure coupled with an enforcement
engine designed to enable scalable automation.

GBP is currently an Open Source stackforge project. It was originally
conceived and presented during the OpenStack Icehouse Design Summit, Hong Kong,
in Nov 2013 [2]. It has evolved through discussions that happened in the
subsequent design summits [3][4], in weekly IRC meetings since Dec 2013 [5],
mailing list discussions in openstack-dev, in #openstack-gbp, and coding
sprints [6].

The GBP core team has ten reviewers [7] who were chosen based on their design
and code contributions to the project. The project follows standard OpenStack
practices with designs being discussed in gerrit specs [8], public code reviews
[9], bugs tracked in Launchpad, a test-driven gate, and stable branches.

GBP leverages other OpenStack services such as Keystone, Neutron,
Nova, Heat, Horizon, and aims to integrate with other services to
comprehensively manage and automate policy enforcement across infrastructure
components.

GBP has an extensible architecture that allows for plugging in open source and
vendor policy drivers. It integrates with the OpenDaylight Network Controller,
and three other vendor backends, with others being planned. GBP has its own
client package, and also UI and automation packages, that plug into Horizon and
Heat respectively. GBP Juno release is available with packages for Fedora, Red
Hat, Ubuntu, and also devstack-based install for developers [10].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy
[2]
http://icehousedesignsummit.sched.org/event/e914b45ccce0b6f70b8b6fce6b0f19af
[3]
http://junodesignsummit.sched.org/event/e9dd467daf0cae0cdb29ee97d64bbf56#.VPI17rPF-Q0
[4]
http://kilodesignsummit.sched.org/event/98dc4255384e340682137c8a7ee7e60d#.VPI2d7PF-Q0
[5] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Neutron_Group_Policy
[6] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy/JunoCodeSprint
[7] https://review.openstack.org/#/admin/groups/438,members
[8] https://github.com/stackforge/group-based-policy-specs
[9]
https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:stackforge/group-based-policy+branch:master,n,z
[10] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy#Try_Group-based_Policy

Change-Id: I0ba6c72a20cf8504dac672d423bd2b80fcd8fd2b

Group Based Policy (GBP) [1] is a policy framework for cloud infrastructure.
It is based on declarative, intent-based abstractions that build on existing
OpenStack interfaces to enable scalable automation.

GBP is currently an Open Source stackforge project. It was originally
conceived and presented during the OpenStack Icehouse Design Summit, Hong Kong,
in Nov 2013 [2]. It has evolved through discussions that happened in the
subsequent design summits [3][4], in weekly IRC meetings since Dec 2013 [5],
mailing list discussions in openstack-dev, in #openstack-gbp, and coding
sprints [6].

GBP has an elected PTL [7] and a core team of ten reviewers [8] who were chosen
based on their design and code contributions to the project. The project follows
standard OpenStack practices with designs being discussed in gerrit specs [8],
public code reviews [10], bugs tracked in Launchpad, a test-driven gate, and
stable branches. The project has a diverse set of contributors spanning
many organizations [11].

GBP leverages other OpenStack services such as Keystone, Neutron,
Nova, Heat, Horizon, and aims to integrate with other services to
comprehensively manage and automate policy enforcement across infrastructure
components.

GBP has an extensible architecture that allows for plugging in open source and
vendor policy drivers. It integrates with the OpenDaylight Network Controller,
and three other vendor backends, with others being planned. GBP has its own
client package, and also UI and automation packages, that plug into Horizon and
Heat respectively. GBP Juno release is available with packages for Fedora, Red
Hat, Ubuntu, and also devstack-based install for developers [12].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy
[2] http://icehousedesignsummit.sched.org/event/e914b45ccce0b6f70b8b6fce6b0f19af
[3] http://junodesignsummit.sched.org/event/e9dd467daf0cae0cdb29ee97d64bbf56#.VPI17rPF-Q0
[4] http://kilodesignsummit.sched.org/event/98dc4255384e340682137c8a7ee7e60d#.VPI2d7PF-Q0
[5] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Neutron_Group_Policy
[6] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy/JunoCodeSprint
[7] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-March/059317.html
[8] https://review.openstack.org/#/admin/groups/438,members
[9] https://github.com/stackforge/group-based-policy-specs
[10] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:stackforge/group-based-policy+branch:master,n,z
[11] http://stackalytics.com/?project_type=stackforge&module=group-based-policy-group&metric=commits&release=all

commit_message:
WIP - Add Group Based Policy Project

Group Based Policy (GBP) [1] is a policy framework for cloud infrastructure.
It is based on declarative, intent-based abstractions that build on existing
OpenStack interfaces to enable scalable automation.

GBP is currently an Open Source stackforge project. It was originally
conceived and presented during the OpenStack Icehouse Design Summit, Hong Kong,
in Nov 2013 [2]. It has evolved through discussions that happened in the
subsequent design summits [3][4], in weekly IRC meetings since Dec 2013 [5],
mailing list discussions in openstack-dev, in #openstack-gbp, and coding
sprints [6].

GBP has an elected PTL [7] and a core team of ten reviewers [8] who were chosen
based on their design and code contributions to the project. The project follows
standard OpenStack practices with designs being discussed in gerrit specs [8],
public code reviews [10], bugs tracked in Launchpad, a test-driven gate, and
stable branches. The project has a diverse set of contributors spanning
many organizations [11].

GBP leverages other OpenStack services such as Keystone, Neutron,
Nova, Heat, Horizon, and aims to integrate with other services to
comprehensively manage and automate policy enforcement across infrastructure
components. The project has designated liaisons [12] to help collaborate with
other project teams and keep GBP in sync with the rest of the ecosystem.

GBP has an extensible architecture that allows for plugging in open source and
vendor policy drivers. It integrates with the OpenDaylight Network Controller,
and three other vendor backends, with others being planned. GBP has its own
client package, and also UI and automation packages, that plug into Horizon and
Heat respectively. GBP Juno release is available with packages for Fedora, Red
Hat, Ubuntu, and also devstack-based install for developers [13].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy
[2] http://icehousedesignsummit.sched.org/event/e914b45ccce0b6f70b8b6fce6b0f19af
[3] http://junodesignsummit.sched.org/event/e9dd467daf0cae0cdb29ee97d64bbf56#.VPI17rPF-Q0
[4] http://kilodesignsummit.sched.org/event/98dc4255384e340682137c8a7ee7e60d#.VPI2d7PF-Q0
[5] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Neutron_Group_Policy
[6] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy/JunoCodeSprint
[7] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-March/059317.html
[8] https://review.openstack.org/#/admin/groups/438,members
[9] https://github.com/stackforge/group-based-policy-specs
[10] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:stackforge/group-based-policy+branch:master,n,z
[11] http://stackalytics.com/?project_type=stackforge&module=group-based-policy-group&metric=commits&release=all
[12] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy#GBP_Cross_Project_Liaisons
[13] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GroupBasedPolicy#Try_Group-based_Policy

Customer Applications running behind Neutron LB in multiple regions.

endpoints.

commit_message:
Add new project Kosmos

Kosmos is a new project, formed initially from members of Designate
and Neutron Lbaas, to provide global server load-balancing for
openstack clouds.

This is separate from both LBaaS and Designate, but heavily leverages
both.

Our long term aim is to create a global service (like Designate /
Keystone) that allows cloud users to balance their traffic across
multiple regions, or multiple cloud providers.

Both Neutron LBaaS and Designate will be first class citizens - the
default install for Kosmos will use both, but we are adopting a plugin
architecture that allows for different integrations, while maintaining
a consistent API.

A standard setup may look like this:

Customer Applications running behind Neutron LB in multiple regions.

Kosmos will constantly monitor these endpoints, and the LBaaS Status
API, and update DNS records in Designate to move traffic between the
endpoints.

Change-Id: I5ed4e8cea5e467cd04a4a44aa9f9c941a1b1b37d

commit_message:
Add Compass to OpenStack Projects

The mission of Compass is to provide an extensible deployment and management framework
for OpenStack, and other distributed systems. It is currently an active project under
 stackforge. It currently supports OpenStack, Ceph, and OPNFV. Compass allows pluggible
underlying configuration management such as Ansible, Chef, etc. It also provides metadata
support, REST API and metadata-driven web UI. This allows a uniform API and Web-UI for
different flavors of OpenStack and its eco-system components, such as ODL, ONOS etc.

Adoption of Compass will help the community in ease-of-use of OpenStack, and will
empower eco-system buildup.

Compass project conforms to our community's four opens as specified in
http://governance.openstack.org/reference/new-projects-requirements.html

  1) Open Source: Apache v2.0 License.

  2) Open Development: we have been using stackforge and OpenStack tool chains since
  the start of the project. This includes gerrit code review, test-driven gates from
  community and our own CI, etc. The PTL acts as the liaison for cross-project teams,
  which includes collaborations within Openstack(Ironic, TripleO), and eco-systems such
  as OPNFV.

  3) Open Design. We presented at earlier design summits, and will continue to do so in
  the future. Blueprints on launchpad. We will also use IRC and openstack-dev ML to
  discuss design.

  4) Open Community. We have scheduled and will conduct weekly IRC meeting. We are also
  open to OPNFV community, and currently in active joint development of Intel's upcoming
  RSA(Rack Scale Architecture).

Related links:
  - wiki page: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Compass
  - project site: http://www.syscompass.org/
  - project in OPNFV: https://wiki.opnfv.org/compass4nfv

Change-Id: I6aacbf1e5bc295757d20d44ce6f4c8db23da1bfc

commit_message:
Add kolla to requirements family

Kolla would like to conform to the global requirements process
to be easy tested and integrated. To be able to do that,
gitdb and GitPython is needed to add in global requirements.
gitdb:
 it is actively maintained at:
     https://github.com/gitpython-developers/gitdb
 lioense:
   New BSD License
GitPython:
 it is actively maintained at:
      https://github.com/gitpython-developers/GitPython
 license:
    New BSD License.
We also not have any other libraries in our global requirements
which provide such functionality.
Change-Id: Id1044b44b21737e57122e892b0330d98623b6108

commit_message:
[zmq][matchmaker] Distinguish targets by listener types

In order to have a possibility to pass messages via different
pipelines (not over DEALER/ROUTER only) we need an information
in the name service about socket type assigned to the target.

Change-Id: I7cdba6c2c91af7f63ecca30c94faecef2c2eff8b
Closes-Bug: #1497326

commit_message:
Enable Protractor end-to-end testing.

This enables end-to-end testing with Protractor, along with some
basic route and page load testing for the home and project pages.
PhantomJS is used to execute tests, and API requests are mocked
using `protractor-http-mock` (see `test/e2e/mocks/`).

A new gulp `e2e` task is also added to prepare and execute the
tests, along with a shortcut, `npm run protractor`. The default
`npm run test` is also amended to include E2E tests, with unit
tests moved to the new shortcut `npm run unit`.

Change-Id: Idb2eef2d851035c715e23553db56fc80deeab8e7

commit_message:
include some details about how we want commit messages structured

When trying to find a particular release request, it's more useful to
have the name of the thing and the version than a description like "fix
bug XYZ".

Change-Id: Ia42b76b7e27f0d24f50cacde15afb3087a2e75ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/01/243801/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Set the first line (summary) of the commit message to the package name and version being requested. * If you are not the release liaison or PTL, have the PTL of the project acknowledge the request with a +1. * Make sure the summary of the patch includes the deliverable name and version number.

commit_message:
[zmq] Update zmq-deployment guide according to the new driver

New driver introduced some new options and changed its architecture.
The first update of the deployment guide after the driver being
reimplemented. Following driver updates should be reflected in the
guide as well.

Change-Id: Id8629907560e335dfcff688082fe943b3657568c
Closes-Bug: #1497278
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/32/244132/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 0MQ (also known as ZeroMQ or zmq) is embeddable networking library but acts like a concurrency framework. It gives you sockets that carry atomic messages across various transports------------------------DummyMatchMaker: default matchmaker driver for all-in-one scenario (messagesRedisMatchMaker: loads the hash table from a remote Redis server, supports rpc_zmq_matchmaker = dummyTo specify the Redis server for RedisMatchMaker, use options in----------------------------------If deploying the RedisMatchMaker, a Redis server is required. Each (K, V) pair Proxy to avoid blocking (optional) ---------------------------------- Each machine running OpenStack services, or sending RPC messages, may run the 'oslo-messaging-zmq-broker' daemon. This is needed to avoid blocking if a listener (server) appears after the sender (client). Running the local broker (proxy) or not is defined by the option 'zmq_use_broker' (True by default). This option can be set in [DEFAULT] section. For example:: zmq_use_broker = False In case of using the broker all publishers (clients) talk to servers over the local broker connecting to it via IPC transport. oslo-messaging-zmq-broker --log-file /var/log/oslo/zmq-broker.log----------------------------Currently zmq driver uses dynamic port binding mechanism, which means that each listener will allocate port of a random number. Ports range is controlled by two options 'rpc_zmq_min_port' and 'rpc_zmq_max_port'. Change them to restrict current service's port binding range. For example:: rpc_zmq_min_port = 9050 rpc_zmq_max_port = 10050 In local.conf [localrc] section need to enable zmq plugin which lives in `devstack-plugin-zmq`_ repository. For example:: enable_plugin zmq https://github.com/openstack/devstack-plugin-zmq.git .. _devstack-plugin-zmq: https://github.com/openstack/devstack-plugin-zmq.git --------------
deleted_lines: 0MQ (also known as ZeroMQ or zmq) looks like an embeddable networking library but acts like a concurrency framework. It gives you sockets that carry atomic messages across various transports-------------------------MatchMakerLocalhost: default matchmaker driver for all-in-one scenario (messagesMatchMakerRing: loads a static hash table from a JSON file, sends messages to a certain host via directed topics or cycles hosts per bare topic and supports broker-less fanout messaging. On fanout messages returns an array of directed topics (messages are sent to all destinations). MatchMakerRedis: loads the hash table from a remote Redis server, supports rpc_zmq_matchmaker = local or rpc_zmq_matchmaker = ringTo specify the ring file for MatchMakerRing, use option 'ringfile' in [matchmaker_ring]. For example:: [matchmaker_ring] ringfile = /etc/oslo/oslo_matchmaker_ring.json To specify the Redis server for MatchMakerRedis, use options in-----------------------------------If deploying the MatchMakerRing, a ring file is required. The format of the ring file should contain a hash where each key is a base topic and the values are hostname arrays to be sent to. For example:: /etc/oslo/oslo_matchmaker_ring.json { "scheduler": ["host1", "host2"], "conductor": ["host1", "host2"], } The AMQP-based methods like RabbitMQ and Qpid don't require any knowledge about the source and destination of any topic. However, ZeroMQ driver with MatchMakerRing does. The challenging task is that you should learn and get all the (K, V) pairs from each OpenStack project to make up the matchmaker ring file. If deploying the MatchMakerRedis, a Redis server is required. Each (K, V) pairMessage Receivers (mandatory) ------------------------------- Each machine running OpenStack services, or sending RPC messages, must run the 'oslo-messaging-zmq-receiver' daemon. This receives replies to call requests and routes responses via IPC to blocked callers. The way that deploy the receiver process is to run it under a new user 'oslo' and give all openstack daemons access via group membership of 'oslo' - this supports using /var/run/openstack as a shared IPC directory for all openstack processes, allowing different services to be hosted on the same server, served by a single oslo-messaging-zmq-receiver process. oslo-messaging-zmq-receiver --log-file /var/log/oslo/zmq-receiver.logThread Pool (optional) ----------------------- Each service will launch threads for incoming requests. These threads are maintained via a pool, the maximum number of threads is limited by rpc_thread_pool_size. The default value is 1024. (This is a common RPC configuration variable, also applicable to Kombu and Qpid) This configuration can be set in [DEFAULT] section. For example:: rpc_thread_pool_size = 1024---------------------------------------------

commit_message:
force_config_drive: StrOpt -> BoolOpt

The 'force_config_drive' option provides a way to force injection of
configuration drives on instances. Previously, this option supported
three values: 'always', 'True' and 'False'. However, the 'always'
value was deprecated in Liberty and can now be removed.

Remove this value and replace the existing 'StrOpt' with a 'BoolOpt'.
This also requires changing some unit tests to reflect the new value
for this parameter.

UpgradeImpact: This change removes support for the 'always' option.
    Configuration files providing this value will need to be updated
    accordingly.
DocImpact: This option is now a BoolOpt and documentation will need to
    be updated accordingly.
Change-Id: I0b4030ec1336fb1f2e721570c99a27a979e2847c

NOTE: The "always" will be deprecated in ' 'the Liberty release cycle.'), if CONF.force_config_drive == 'always': LOG.warning(_LW('The setting "always" will be deprecated in the ' 'Liberty version. commit_message:
Avoid requesting get-pip.py multiple times

This patch prevents the contents of get-pip.py from being printed to the
console and it avoids retrieving the script more than once via curl unless
absolutely necessary.

Closes-bug: 1514988

Change-Id: I6b312dfac23c8b32dba71edcfc65f65858349893
(cherry picked from commit 2690d81c23e9c68be6be302fb0b86854e1a16ddd)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/86/244686/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If GET_PIP_URL is set, then just use it curl --silent ${GET_PIP_URL} > /opt/get-pip.py if head -n 1 /opt/get-pip.py | grep python; then python2 /opt/get-pip.py || python /opt/get-pip.py return # Try getting pip from bootstrap.pypa.io as a primary source curl --silent https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py > /opt/get-pip.py if head -n 1 /opt/get-pip.py | grep python; then python2 /opt/get-pip.py || python /opt/get-pip.py return fi # Try the get-pip.py from the github repository as a secondary source curl --silent https://raw.github.com/pypa/pip/master/contrib/get-pip.py > /opt/get-pip.py if head -n 1 /opt/get-pip.py | grep python; then python2 /opt/get-pip.py || python /opt/get-pip.py return fi echo "A suitable download location for get-pip.py could not be found." exit_fail
deleted_lines: # if GET_PIP_URL is set, then just use it # Find and use an available get-pip download location. if curl --silent https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py; then export GET_PIP_URL='https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py' elif curl --silent https://raw.github.com/pypa/pip/master/contrib/get-pip.py; then export GET_PIP_URL='https://raw.github.com/pypa/pip/master/contrib/get-pip.py' else echo "A suitable download location for get-pip.py could not be found." exit_fail # Download and install pip curl ${GET_PIP_URL} > /opt/get-pip.py python2 /opt/get-pip.py || python /opt/get-pip.py

commit_message:
display release:independent projects on a separate page

Show all of the release:independent projects release histories on a
separate page, now that they have moved out of the release series
directories.

Change-Id: I3fddbca590b1a8fcacc180a2730f0463dbcc0100

commit_message:
Move independent project releases

Remove from Liberty release page all deliverables that actually
don't have a stable/liberty branch (since they, in effect, don't
have a "liberty" release at all). Store those in a specific
releases directory.

Change-Id: I63cc10163dcc50c67ff23bd807b1a91394de7dc2

commit_message:
diff_branches: use jinja templates to create the files

Generating docbook using lxml works fine, but the switch to RST tables
will make the code more diffiicult to read and maintain. Using jinja
templates will shorten the code and avoid dealing with complicated code.

This patch implements the use of jinja for docbook tables, and will ease
the implementation of RST output.

Change-Id: Ia5a75ced773b7e6e8faa7f89cb7620d986c47718

commit_message:
Final decomposition of opendaylight driver

It's all in networking-odl now.

Closes-Bug: #1514823

Depends-On: Ibc6fa46b9bae73c045bec71894ebe3cad570edcc

Change-Id: I76ae1a5078e4a47ee901150d4832f06c1d1ab093

commit_message:
Updated from global requirements

Stolen from Ic7516b79ed1eea1330f008ce83c8727fd974bdd3 and added a forced
oslo.config:

   NOTE(tonyb) Horizon itself doesn't need oslo.config but
   django-openstack-auth (doa) 1.1.9 (which meets the requirements
   below) contains an uncapped dependancy on oslo.config.  Force this
   *BEFORE* doa so that when doa is installed the requirement is already
   met and 2.x isn;t installed.

Change-Id: I5c8d0b97b52535b2c0c3501aa7b16ef497768731

commit_message:
Fix check for local IPs in DNS upstream

Value loading and checking for DNS upstream now
ensures that any host IP is excluded from DNS
upstream values.

New function list_host_ip_addresses returns IPv4
addresses for specified or all network interfaces.

Change-Id: I4b9ba582dfe498d89f0344b7dee1b1dff775ae9f
Closes-Bug: #1513844

New common.network method is_physical returns true
if the string 'virtual' is not in its sysfs realpath.

Change-Id: I8d5f0fbcc1426a94b433d1a097fb51cc6915c154
Closes-Bug: #1512479
"}]
commit_message:
Unhardcode default interface from eth0

Now the first detected physical interface will be
used as the default network interface. If for any
reason no physical interfaces are detected, fuelmenu
will exit with an error.

New common.network method get_physical_ifaces returns
a sorted list of interfaces that are physical

New common.network method is_physical returns true
if the string 'virtual' is not in its sysfs realpath.

Change-Id: I8d5f0fbcc1426a94b433d1a097fb51cc6915c154
Closes-Bug: #1512479

deleted_lines: re_ifaces = re.compile(r"lo|vir|vbox|docker|veth") for iface in netifaces.interfaces(): if re_ifaces.search(iface): continue

commit_message:
Don't use duplicate filter names for functional testing

They are not supported by Python 3.x configparser module (you get
DuplicateOptionError if duplicate names are present).

This makes tests relying on rootwrap daemon to get stuck, because the daemon
fails to spawn, while we wait for results from the process.

Change-Id: I1628bb87b235a6b4bac53afda37402e986520f39
Related-Bug: #1515118

commit_message:
Make task parameter mandatory in get_supported_boot_devices

Deprecation period for not having task parameter in
get_supported_boot_devices is over, this change removes this
possibility and also adds now required parameter to UCS management
interface.

Change-Id: Id049f040865abf4c2dd50e8d91c227b67c9204b9

commit_message:
Use PCS's maintenance mode while updating configuration

During upgrades and updates where configuration is edited service restarts
can be triggered.  If pacemaker isn't in maintenance mode it may attempt to
restart the service while it's being restarted.  This in turn results in
failed deployments and failed stack updates.

This change enables "maintenance-mode" for steps 1-3 where configuration
is still being landed and services may get restarted automatically.

Change-Id: Ibbb86d6ed8221c47acef9383848eb7230fe59b7c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/41/242141/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This is the point at which we allow pace maker to manage services, if we do # this before the services are configured we can trigger restarts which result # in puppet run failures $pcmk_start = hiera('step') >= 3 if $pacemaker_master { if $pcmk_start { exec { 'DISABLE maintentance': command => '/usr/sbin/pcs property set maintenance-mode=false', onlyif => '/usr/sbin/pcs property show maintenance-mode | grep "maintenance-mode=true"', require => Class['::pacemaker::corosync'], } Pacemaker::Resource::Service { require => Exec['DISABLE maintentance']. } } else { exec { 'ENABLE maintentance': command => '/usr/sbin/pcs property set maintenance-mode=true', onlyif => '/usr/sbin/pcs property show maintenance-mode | grep "maintenance-mode=false"', require => Class['::pacemaker::corosync'], } Pacemaker::Resource::Service { require => Exec['ENABLE maintentance']. } } }

commit_message:
[Murano Docs] Create an environment

Adds a HowTo instruction into the "Create an environment"
section of the End User Guide.

Change-Id: I265badd2649473b173ce899e461eb5fba5ecced3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/15/244115/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: To create an environment, perform the following steps: #. In OpenStack Dashboard, navigate to Murano > Application Catalog > Environments. #. On the :guilabel:`Environments` page, click the :guilabel:`Add New` button. #. In the :guilabel:`Environment Name` field, enter the name for the new environment. #. From the :guilabel:`Environment Default Network` drop-down list, choose a specific network, if necessary, or leave the default :guilabel:`Create New` option to generate a new network. #. Click the rightmost :guilabel:`Create` button. You will be redirected to the page with the environment components.
